title: Will my teacher see that I have submitted (‘marked as done’) my assignment on Google Classroom before the deadline which I did, because I forgot to click ‘turn in’, and now, it says ‘turned in late’? - Quora

response.answer_text: Teachers can see the date and time when something was submitted and worked on. So the system does keep track of dates and times. Providing teachers with documentation to show, this is the date and time, when something was posted or uploaded or completed. Now what happened with you is you didn’t click the 𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘯 𝘪𝘯 button. So the system thinks you were working on it but never actually turned it in for grading. And that’s why the system is saying it’s late. However, your teacher can look at it, see it was fully completed, and just give you full credit by realizing you must have forgotten to hit the 𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘯 𝘪𝘯 button. But then again, your teacher may just see the late submission and date it was last worked on or accessed, yet treat it as late because it was your fault for not hitting the 𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘯 𝘪𝘯 button. If you haven’t already done so, I would suggest you contact your teacher and let him or her know what happened. But it’s still up to the individual teacher how to handle it because it was your own fault for forgetting to click the 𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘯 𝘪𝘯 button. So one teacher may understand and give you full credit. Another may understand yet still not give you full or partial credit because it was your mistake not a system problem or teacher error.

It shows the submitted date which will be considered late. You may have a way to show it was completed before the date depending on the nature of the document you turned in. If the program used to create the document has a last edited or saved on date and time you could at least show it was completed, but not turned in on time. We could also open a debate on what is the most important, your mastery of the assignment or the amount of time it took you to finish? With many of my students receiving extra time, I've allowed all to take extra time and grade primarily on how well they master the subject.
